titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

physDesc.p: M1-8-6. [The readers faculty is a queer one...]. Holograph. In back [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 21-TK

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: The readers faculty is a queer one. He has the power to make
houses & countries visible as through the printed page; men &
women, & their emotions & thoughts; He has also the more
the sense of & [birdes?], a sense of their relations; whether
the emotion [emtubates?], or dissipates. And BAnd he is
alwauys limited by his time. What is visible to one
generation, is lost [not?] to another. He is not interested in
language. texts. He does not pass He is not a scholar; not & so
[laiks?] may & the critics fools. And And yet, with all
And yet he is exercising quite another faculty than the
newspaper reader. And one that millions of the literate
are without. Often he is himself a writer. This gives
him a queer [arc? after?] of vision. The And he is
sensitive to a voice that becomes increasingly audible –
It would be a [illeg.] Now & again it is to be

l.del: heard even in the 16th centruy: even the

other influences, was palpable to the personality – so

No scholar will ever now disciver them. What we

actors to convey. a generalised tendency.

to feel that he is, more than any other poet,

p.l: he is not, as so many writers are, the
He does not, as so many writers do, feed
momentary appetites & all readers who
are themselves writers, feel at inexplicable
hunger, for certain styles, for certain forms.
Shre Shakespeare's styles are so innumerable that he never
lowers as to to clear up any particular points
any the He can as [soon?] be read, when the
ink has gone dry on the pen, to restore language
He can give the general sense of speed.
But the style & the [scope?] make him
unsuitable, unless, for the writer as a model.
